item.title: Spurs show progress in draw against Arsenal
item.description: Level on points with Arsenal, five wins from nine and the most clean sheets in the Women's Super League this season - Tottenham are in a good place.

item.title: Frank had 'unique' Man Utd & Chelsea talks on same day
item.description: Tottenham manager Thomas Frank had talks with both Chelsea and Manchester United on the same day last year.

item.title: Scots 'can't let go' of World Cup chance - McGinn
item.description: Scotland "can't let go" of the opportunity they have to reach a first men's World Cup since 1998, says midfielder John McGinn.

item.title: The permutations as Wales target World Cup
item.description: How Wales' final World Cup qualifier against North Macedonia on Tuesday can impact Group J.

item.title: Injured Arsenal defender Gabriel to miss Brazil game
item.description: Arsenal defender Gabriel will miss Brazil's game on Tuesday after scans confirmed a thigh injury.

item.title: Chelsea set new WSL unbeaten record with draw at Liverpool
item.description:
Women's Super League title holders Chelsea drop points for just the third time this season after a 1-1 draw against Liverpool.
Women's Super League title holders Chelsea drop points for just the third time this season after a 1-1 draw against Liverpool.

item.title: Alex Scott takes on Australian 'This or That?'
item.description: Football Focus presenter Alex Scott prepares for jungle life in I'm a Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here as she takes on an Australian-themed "This or That?".

item.title: Highlights: Scotland go down in five-goal thriller in Greece
item.description: Watch highlights as Scotland lose 3-2 in Greece but still have hope of automatic qualification for next summer's World Cup after Denmark are held to a 2-2 draw by Belarus.

item.title: Hemp hits 'absolute rocket' to give Man City 3-0 lead
item.description: Manchester City's Lauren Hemp scores an "absolute rocket" to make it 3-0 against rivals Manchester United in the Women's Super League.

item.title: Kumagai scores twice to give London City win over Aston Villa
item.description: Saki Kumagai scores two headers as London City Lionesses secure their fifth win in the WSL with a 3-1 defeat over Aston Villa .

item.title: Italy fighting to avoid another 'apocalyptic' World Cup failure
item.description: Four-time winners Italy are one of the most successful nations in World Cup history - but are in danger of missing the finals for the third successive time.

item.title: 'Scotland resuscitated after World Cup dream almost dies thrilling death'
item.description: BBC Sport Scotland chief sportswriter Tom English dissects Scotland's World Cup chances after dramatic lifeline from Belarus.

item.title: Fifa reports 30,000 abusive online posts this year
item.description: Fifa says 11 people were reported to law enforcement authorities in 2025 and one case was submitted to Interpol.

item.title: Sky Sports axes 'sexist' TikTok channel Halo after three days
item.description: The female-focused TikTok channel was dubbed "patronising" and "sexist" by social media users.

item.title: Who is I'm a Celebrity's Alex Scott?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything Team look at the career of former Lioness and Arsenal player turned I'm A Celebrity Contestant Alex Scott.

item.title: Do you know the players in England's latest squad?
item.description: With England facing Albania can you name all 10 of these players who were in manager Thomas Tuchel's initial squad?

item.title: Who would you pick for Wales' qualifier v North Macedonia?
item.description: It's a must win game to improve Wales path to the 2026 World Cup - who would you pick in your team to face North Macedonia?

item.title: Are Scotland threatening to turn glorious failure on its head?
item.description: After years of admirable misery, are Scotland destined for the World Cup after riding their luck in their qualification campaign?

item.title: How dazzling Hemp can boost Man City's title hopes
item.description: When you are already top of the WSL table and are able to recall a fully fit Lauren Hemp, you know you are in a strong position.

item.title: Banned Bellamy 'calm' as Wales claim unimpressive Liechtenstein win
item.description: Stand-in boss Piet Cremers says banned head coach Craig Bellamy was "calm" about Wales' unconvincing win in Liechtenstein.

item.title: NI 'won't fear anyone' in World Cup play-off draw - Bradley
item.description: Northern Ireland's Conor Bradley says there is "no point" being intimidated by the level of opposition they will face in their play-off for the 2026 World Cup.

item.title: Anderson Man Utd's priority target - Sunday's gossip
item.description: Elliot Anderson is a winter target for Manchester United and England striker Ivan Toney will reportedly not leave Saudi Arabia in January.

item.title: Ampadu 'gutted' to miss crunch North Macedonia tie
item.description: Ethan Ampadu is "gutted" to be suspended for Tuesday's decisive final World Cup qualifying group game against North Macedonia.

item.title: Five years of Hollywood owners - the Wrexham timeline
item.description: Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenneyâ€™s takeover of Wrexham has seen the Welsh club rise from National League to Championship with three successive promotions.

item.title: Match abandoned after 'sexist' abuse of referee
item.description: AFC Rushden & Diamonds says it is "deeply concerned" by the comment made to the female referee.

item.title: Manager Hughes sacked by struggling Newport
item.description: David Hughes leaves his role as Newport County manager after six months in charge.

item.title: Croatia through - what's still at stake in final World Cup qualifiers?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team looks at who has qualified for next year's Fifa World Cup.

item.title: NI focus on play-off after Slovakia sucker punch
item.description: With Northern Ireland now guaranteed a World Cup play-off in March, BBC Sport NI's Jonathan Bradley reflects on their qualifying campaign.

item.title: Thelwell seeks 'greater quality of refereeing'
item.description: Sporting director Kevin Thelwell says Rangers want "greater consistency, greater quality and standard of refereeing".

item.title: Referee needed to 'be stronger' - O'Neill
item.description: Northern Ireland manager Michael O'Neill says the yellow card he was shown at the end of his side's 1-0 defeat by Slovakia was for telling the referee to "be stronger".

item.title: Is anything being done about poor player behaviour?
item.description: Player behaviour didn't feature in Reinventing Football, our manifesto for the game, but it was a big focus for fans.

item.title: 'VAR has to rein its neck in' - how I'd change football for the fans
item.description: In his BBC Sport column, former Premier League manager Tony Pulis looks at which laws he would change in football.

item.title: Could a stopped clock end time-wasting in football?
item.description: Would a game of two halves of 30 minutes, with the watch stopped when the ball is out, really improve football?

item.title: How new rules would change way football is played
item.description: BBC Sport has been looking at possible ways of changing football - but what impact could different laws have on tactics?

item.title: The Ratcliffe revolution - inside Man Utd's exodus and rebuild
item.description: BBC Sport tells the story of how Sir Jim Ratcliffe ripped apart and rebuilt Manchester United's leadership team.

item.title: The great number nine decline - where have England's strikers gone?
item.description: BBC Sport takes an in-depth look at why England lack centre-forward options behind Harry Kane - a far cry from when the likes of Les Ferdinand only won 17 caps.

item.title: Meet the man who played in two games, in two countries... in one day
item.description: BBC Sport tells the story of Soren Lerby, who once played for Denmark and Bayern Munich on the same day - in different countries.

item.title: Former defender Edwards' return to Wolves - a gamble all round?
item.description: Wolves finally have their man. But how big a gamble have the Premier League side made in appointing Rob Edwards?

item.title: 1,000 games in, Guardiola has new energy for new era
item.description: Sunday began with a celebration of Pep Guardiola and ended in the same manner, with the Manchester City boss showing he has new energy in a new era for the club.

item.title: Transfers - September to December 2025
item.description: Check out the significant signings and departures in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, EFL and Women's Super League.

item.title: Manager ins and outs - 2025-26 season
item.description: BBC Sport tracks all the manager ins and outs in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, Women's Super League, English Football League and National League.

item.title: Why are England called the Three Lions?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explain where the three lions on the England shirt came from.

item.title: When is the 2026 World Cup draw?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explore when the World Cup draw is, how the seeding works and who has qualified so far.

item.title: Who is Wilfried Nancy?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team take a look who MLS manager Wilfried Nancy is.

item.title: Why VAR gets involved in some penalties but not others
item.description: It was a weekend of VAR penalty decisions in the Premier League, with spot-kicks awarded, cancelled and ignored. BBC Sport explains why.

item.title: Why can Channel Islands players play for England?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team look at why players born in the Channel Islands like Alex Scott can represent England at a senior level.

item.title: What are the Fifa Best Awards?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explain what the Fifa Best Awards are, who can vote and who the nominees are.

item.title: Why do footballers tape up their wrists?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explains why footballers use tape to wrap their wrists.

item.title: Your team talk to inspire Scotland to World Cup
item.description: Put yourself in the shoes of the Scotland manager and pick the side and tactics and decide what your pre-match team talk would be.

item.title: Maccabi fan ban was due to hooliganism, say police
item.description: West Midlands Police did not previously reveal its reasons because "it wasn't deemed helpful".

item.title: Referees among suspects sought in match-fixing probe
item.description: Turkish prosecutors issue detention orders for 21 people - including 17 referees and two club presidents - as part of a major investigation into betting and match fixing.

item.title: From farming village to Liverpool icon - the Salah story
item.description: BBC Sport visits Egypt to discover what Mohamed Salah means to the people of the football-mad country, and how a small boy from humble beginnings became a national icon.

item.title: Napoli 'smell blood' & target Premier League's discarded stars
item.description: After Scott McTominay was a hit, Napoli went back to the Premier League for Kevin de Bruyne, could more players follow them to Serie A?

item.title: How does Daniel Levy run Tottenham - and would he ever leave?
item.description: With Tottenham struggling on the pitch and chairman Daniel Levy facing criticism from fans, BBC Sport looks at how the club is run and what the future might hold.

item.title: When River Plate icon Diaz took over fourth-tier Oxford
item.description: Twenty years on from Ramon Diaz's surprising appointment at Oxford United, BBC Sport looks at what happened and how it went.

item.title: East meets west London - the mentor who changed Chelsea
item.description: Vinay Menon knew nothing about football when he went for a meeting at a west London mansion in 2009. A few weeks later he was in the heart of the Chelsea dressing room.

item.title: The air crash and the underdogs - a triumph for a lost generation
item.description: Nineteen years and 10 miles separated Zambia's football team from a lost, golden generation on a fateful night in Libreville.

item.title: The rise and fall of North Korea - the sleeping giant of women's football
item.description: North Korea lags behind most of the rest of the world in several areas. But the hermit state has had an outsized impact on international women's football.
